title: Chazz Palminteri, de Blasio tussle over saint statue and accusations of racism
text:
Bronx-born Chazz Palminteri had already said he believed the mayor’s wife, Chirlane McCray, was “being racist” by not choosing Saint Francesca Xavier Cabrini to be honored with a statue. | Getty Images Chazz Palminteri, de Blasio tussle over saint statue and accusations of racism

Mayor Bill de Blasio faced off with the star of "A Bronx Tale" on Friday, in a fiery radio segment replete with accusations of racism, charges resembling President Donald Trump’s “fake news” claims and, ultimately, a detente.

Bronx-born Chazz Palminteri had already said he believed the mayor’s wife, Chirlane McCray, was “being racist” by not choosing Saint Francesca Xavier Cabrini to be honored with a statue when he called into the "Brian Lehrer Show" Friday morning to address de Blasio directly.

Story Continued Below

“I’m a very proud Italian-American” Palminteri declared upon calling about 10 minutes into the weekly segment.

He applauded McCray’s initiative, She Built NYC, which is expanding the city’s monuments to include more women and racial minorities.

But Mother Cabrini, who topped the list of potential honorees with 219 nominations, was snubbed, he insisted.

“Here’s a woman who started 67 charities, Mr. Mayor. 67! Here’s a woman who’s the patron saint of immigrants, who has done so much for New York and the world,” Palminteri said.

He said she received “double the votes” of the second-place selection, Jane Jacobs, who had 93 nominations, but isn’t getting the honor of a statue. “Mr. Mayor, how could we just disregard Mother Cabrini and say, ‘Okay, she’s out and these other seven are in?’”

The mayor was primed for the fight.

He asked Lehrer to keep Palminteri on the line so the two could “set the record straight.”

He then said the actor began his remarks “in the right place” by acknowledging the purpose of McCray’s monument initiative and referenced his own Italian heritage.

But de Blasio took issue with Palminteri’s characterization of the contest, saying nominations differ from actual votes.

“It was not an online vote and whoever got the most votes wins,” he said. “There weren’t even that many votes, honestly.”

Palminteri tried to interrupt but de Blasio scolded him: “Chazz, let me finish. Let me finish.”

After praising Mother Cabrini as “an outstanding figure and absolutely worthy of being honored,” he shifted to the actor’s statement that McCray, who is black, is racist for disfavoring a white nominee.

But he offered Palminteri an out.

“I want to set something straight with you, personally and I want to make sure … there’s not a conflict between us because of misreporting by the New York Post,” he said, referencing the conservative tabloid he has been at war with throughout his mayoralty. The Post was actually reporting on quotes Palminteri made to 77 WABC Radio.

“I’ve often said the New York Post doesn’t traffic in facts; it tries oftentimes to divide us and it misrepresents," the mayor said.

“So I’m not going to believe the New York Post. You’re live on the radio. The New York Post says you called my wife, who is a tremendous public servant, who loves people of all backgrounds, who named her children Chiara and Dante and honors their Italian heritage, that you called her a racist,” he said. “I can’t believe you would’ve done that, but I’m sure you’ll tell me the honest truth.”

Palminteri didn’t accept the excuse, saying that “as a man” he could not lie.

“I was asked a question — do you think that is racism? And I did say the word, 'yes,'” he said. “I did not call her a racist. I never said those words. But they asked me, 'do you think that is racism?' And I said 'well it looks that way.'”

“If anything, Mr. Mayor, it’s an implicit bias at the least,” he added.

With that admission, the mayor’s anger shifted.

He told Palminteri to “get it together.”

“Mother Cabrini is going to be talked about in this next round. There’s a great argument for her,” he said. “But you don’t call someone a racist who isn’t a racist. It just isn’t factually right. And it’s inappropriate and it’s unfair.”

He also said Palminteri should have “pick[ed] up the godforsaken phone [to] say, ‘Hey, a lot of us think this is a great idea. Can’t we make this happen?’ And I would’ve said that’s a great idea; let’s get to work on it.”

In fact, he said he would personally lobby for Mother Cabrini to get a statue in the future. Cabrini was canonized by the Catholic Church in 1946 and is the first U.S. immigrant to be sainted.

In a further sign of harmony, Palminteri apologized for his comments.

Lehrer, who was anxious to cover more ground on weighty issues like a pending vote for the closure of Rikers Island’s jail complex, sought to wrap things up.

“Chazz I have to go on to some other calls. I’m sure you understand. I’m going to give you one chance to say after this exchange that you’ve just had with the mayor, do you want to retract the accusation of racism in the selection process or stand by it?” Lehrer asked.

“I would like you to tell your wife I apologize for using the word 'racism,'” Palminteri replied.

It appeared unlikely the mayor would follow suit.

“@NYCMayor, any apology to the @nypost for falsely accusing us of misreporting @chazzpalminteri's comments?” New York Post City Hall bureau chief Julia Marsh tweeted.

Thus far de Blasio has not replied.
description: The mayor was primed for the fight.
